comments.body:
Do we see a reason why we should only allow one of these?  We currently support wrapping transports, so it seems a little unusual that we wouldn't support wrapping these as well.

I don't feel very strongly, but if someone has a use-case for it now (custom headers for some kind of proxy and gcp maybe?) we should build that so that the serialization stays the same.  If no one can think of a valid reason now, a conversion and deprecated field is possible later.
Good point. I can see this being the case for us over the next few months. Were you thinking that this could be a slice instead?

> Good point. I can see this being the case for us over the next few months. Were you thinking that this could be a slice instead?

Yes, with the godoc describing the wrapping order and warning that we provide no protection against one wrapper undoing the work of another wrapper.

+1

On Tue, Mar 22, 2016 at 10:28 AM, David Eads notifications@github.com
wrote:

> In pkg/client/unversioned/clientcmd/api/types.go
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/23066#discussion_r56994711
> :
> 
> > @@ -92,6 +94,8 @@ type AuthInfo struct {
> >     Username string `json:"username,omitempty"`
> >     // Password is the password for basic authentication to the kubernetes cluster.
> >     Password string `json:"password,omitempty"`
> > -   // AuthProvider specifies custom authentication for the kubernetes cluster.
> > -   AuthProvider *AuthProviderConfig `json:"auth-provider,omitempty"`
> 
> Good point. I can see this being the case for us over the next few months.
> Were you thinking that this could be a slice instead?
> 
> Yes, with the godoc describing the wrapping order and warning that we
> provide no protection against one wrapper undoing the work of another
> wrapper.
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/23066/files/6513f0d96e0e699f117afee7b1f59838044980e4#r56994711
A slice SGTM. It adds ~0 complexity to the single-wrapper use case and future-proofs this a little bit.
That makes this more of a removal.  If we're removing it, why aren't we simply removing the entire field?  This will look deceptive anywhere its touchable.
We don't want to break existing config files.
